docs.lead_paragraph: Many children are needlessly kept out of preschool programs because of misunderstandings over what illnesses require them to be kept away from other youngsters, a new study reports. Researchers who surveyed preschool programs, parents and doctors found that many were unfamiliar with national guidelines outlining when children should be kept from school. The study, led by Dr. Kristen Copeland of the Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, was presented last week at a meeting of the Pediatric Academic Societies.

headline.main: Too Sick for School? Maybe Not

docs.snippet: Many children are needlessly kept out of preschool programs because of misunderstandings over what illnesses require them to be kept away from other youngsters, a new study reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: Six months after being given prescriptions for drugs to lower blood pressure and cholesterol, only one patient of three in a new study was still taking the two medications, researchers reported yesterday. People with high cholesterol and blood pressure are at especially high risk for heart problems. But writing in Archives of Internal Medicine, the researchers said it was common for them to stop taking the drugs. The study was led by Dr. Richard H. Chapman of ValueMedics Research, a consulting group. The researchers examined the records of more than 8,400 patients who had been prescribed the two medications and estimated compliance by looking at prescription renewals. The study called the sharp drop ''extremely concerning.''
docs.snippet: Six months after being given prescriptions for drugs to lower blood pressure and cholesterol, only one patient in three in a new study was still taking the two medications.
